module.name: superquadric-model
module.description: Framework for object detecting and modeling.
module.copypolicy: Released under the terms of the GNU GPL v2.0
module.description-long:
This module allows object detection and modelling. You can run it in different modes: - _on-line_, if you want the object to be detected and modeled constantly; - _one-shot_ mode, if you want to compute the superquadric model from a .off _file_, containing the point cloud of interest.
To correctly launch the module, do the following: - Put an object in the robot's sight (for example, on a table in front of it) and make sure that the eye vergence (iCub joints) is equal to the value used during _SFM_ calibration. - Launch IOL application from the _yarpmanager_ (all modules, except for _2 speech modules_ and _lua module_), make the connections and make sure that _SFM_ is giving a good disparity map (otherwise calibrate it thorugh the proper rpc port). - Launch superquadric-model application (_superquadric-model_ module and two _yarpviews_), through the _yarpmanager_ and make all the connections. - Open the rpc port /superquadric-model/rpc to play with the application. A possible rpc command sequence is the following: - $ set_object_name ball (e.g.), if you want to model the object "ball". If the object is known by IOL, the superquadric will be computed, otherwise the application will wait for another object name. - $ get_superq ball returns the 11 parameters of the reconstructed superquadric.
The other possible rpc commands are described in the section Services. The result of the superquadric reconstruction is shown also on the yarpview showing the image caming from the left camera. Here, you can find a visualization of the superquadric, overlapped on the object.
In section Parameters each parameter is labeled as default or advanced parameter. You can change advanced parameter values only if you are skilled with the relative usage. For each parameter, it is also specified if a thrift service is available to play with them while the module is running.
The module execution provides three output files: - _object-name_.txt or output.txt (if the point cloud is given through a file or a seed point), containing the reconstructed superquadric and some information about IPOPT algorithm; - SFM-_object-name_.off containing the 3D points coming from SFM; - filtered-_object-name_.off containing the filtered 3D points (if filtering is enabled).

param.desc: File containing the point cloud to be modeled (default parameter).
Eye used for projection of the 3D points on the superquadric surface to the 2D pixels (default parameter - thrift service available).
Desired convergence tolerance (relative). Determines the convergence tolerance for the IPOPT algorithm (default parameter - thrift service available).

IPOPT acceptable iter. Number of acceptable iterates before triggering termination. If the algorithm encounters this many successive acceptable iterates, it terminates, assuming that the problem has been solved to best possible accuracy given round-off. If it is set to zero, this heuristic is disabled (default parameter).
Maximum cpu time for IPOPT algorithm execution (default parameter - thrift service available).
IPOPT update strategy for barrier parameter. Determines which barrier parameter update strategy is to be used. POssible values: monotone or adaptive (default parameter).
IPOPT nlp_scaling_method: Select the technique used for scaling the problem. Possible values: none, user-scaling, gradient-based, equilibration-based (default parameter).
Variable to decide to filter points or not (default parameter - thrift service available).
Points used by the optimization algorithm to reconstruct the superquadric function (default parameter - thrift service available).
KNN radius value for filtering (advanced parameter - advanced thrift service available).
NKK threshold value for filtering (advanced parameter - advanced thrift service available).

input.description: receive the image from the left camera.

output.description: send the image from the left camera with the visualized superquadric or points.
